channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Putin Promises Victory in Ukraine as His Forces Strike a Key City
item.description: On the 80th anniversary of a decisive Soviet triumph over the Nazis, President Vladimir V. Putin tried to cast Russia’s invasion as a virtuous endeavor. Back-to-back missile strikes hit the Ukrainian military hub of Kramatorsk as Kyiv warned of a new Russian offensive.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: In Congo, a Pope and a Nation Revitalize Each Other
item.description: Francis has been slowed by age. But his enthusiastic welcome in Africa has proved a shot in the arm and provided a reminder of the papacy’s global reach.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Pope Francis on Thursday at Martyrs’ Stadium in Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo. He addressed some 65,000 young people.

item.title: A U.S. Ambassador Finds Himself on Hostile Ground in Hungary
item.description: David Pressman, a gay human rights lawyer, has been accused by pro-government media in Hungary of undermining traditional values, violating diplomatic conventions and meddling in the judiciary.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Pressman posing for a portrait in front of the former National TV headquarters last month in Budapest.

item.title: U.S. to Boost Military Role in the Philippines in Push to Counter China
item.description: Washington and Manila announced a plan to give the American military access to four new locations in the Southeast Asian country, a growing strategic partner in the region.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Jam Sta Rosa
item.media:description: President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. of The Philippines and United States Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin at the presidential palace in Manila, on Thursday.

item.title: Israel’s Government Pushes Home Demolitions as Violence Surges
item.description: Israel defends its policy of leveling the family homes of Palestinians accused of attacks on its citizens as a deterrent. Critics say it is illegal and ineffective.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Afif H. Amireh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers outside the home of the al-Qam family on Sunday. Khairy al-Qam, 21, was recently accused of killing seven people outside a synagogue.

item.title: China and the U.S. Are Wooing Indonesia, and Beijing Has the Edge
item.description: The resource-laden nation of nearly 300 million is a big prize in the strategic battle between the United States and China for influence in Asia.
item.dc:creator: Jane Perlez, Eric Schmitt and Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times
item.media:description: A portrait of China’s leader, Xi Jinping, and Indonesia’s leader, Joko Widodo, at a construction site in Bandung, Indonesia, where a high-speed train station is being built.

item.title: Australia Won’t Put King Charles on Its 5-Dollar Bill
item.description: The bill had long featured Queen Elizabeth II, but officials said the bank note would be redesigned to focus on Indigenous history. That has rekindled the debate about republicanism in Australia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Australia’s prime minister, Anthony Albanese, stands next to a portrait of King Charles III in Canberra, Australia, last month. The longstanding images of the British sovereign will be replaced by an Indigenous element on the 5-dollar note.

item.title: European Parliament Strips 2 Lawmakers of Immunity in Graft Inquiry
item.description: The European Parliament’s move is likely to prompt the arrest of Marc Tarabella of Belgium and Andrea Cozzolino of Italy in connection with claims of influence-peddling involving Qatar and Morocco.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Yves Herman/Reuters; John Thys, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Marc Tarabella of Belgium, left, and Andrea Cozzolino of Italy, right, are members of the center-left Socialists and Democrats group, which is at the heart of the scandal ripping through the European Parliament.

item.title: Why Iran’s Missile Program Alarms Its Regional Rivals
item.description: A drone attack on a military facility in central Iran, said to be the work of Israel’s intelligence agency, focused renewed attention on Tehran’s advancing missile capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: A Ghadr-H missile, center, a solid-fuel surface-to-surface Sejjil missile and a portrait of Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, on display in Tehran in 2017.

item.title: India’s Right Wing Tried to Scuttle the Film ‘Pathaan.’ Fans Helped It Set Records.
item.description: “Pathaan” demonstrated the crosscutting appeal of the Bollywood titan Shah Rukh Khan, who re-emerged on the big screen after a difficult personal period.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: A poster for the Bollywood movie “Pathaan," at a cinema hall in Prayagraj, India, in January.

item.title: A Couple Danced in Tehran’s Streets. Now They Are in Prison.
item.description: Iranian authorities sentenced a young couple to five years in prison after they posted a video of themselves dancing in the streets at the height of the country’s protests.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Images from a video posted on social media showing Astiyazh Haghighi and Amir Mohammad Ahmadi dancing in front of Tehran’s Azadi Tower.

item.title: As China’s Covid Tsunami Recedes, Relief, Grief and Anxiety Follow
item.description: Officials say an onslaught of infections has slowed, and many people seem eager to move on. But fresh flare-ups could bring more illness and deaths.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.category: Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A closed PCR testing booth sits idle in Shanghai. China’s Covid cases fell dramatically and case numbers peaked in December, according to Chinese public health officials.

item.title: Pope Francis Visits Congo: What to Know
item.description: The pope is planning to spend three days in the Democratic Republic of Congo, one of the most populous and most Catholic nations in Africa. While it has extensive natural riches, its people have long been buffeted by conflict and exploitation.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: Internally displaced Congolese carry charcoal from the forest at the foot of Nyiragongo Volcano in Virunga National Park to the market in Kibati, this month.

item.title: Asia Is Loosening Rules on Masks. Here’s Why People Still Wear Them.
item.description: Many other countries dropped pandemic mask requirements months ago. But in places like South Korea, which got rid of its rule this week, masks remain common.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Hikari Hida
item.media:description: A bookstore in Seoul on Monday, after South Korea lifted its indoor mask mandate as Covid cases dwindle.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Russian losses in the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Near Kyiv, mourning a soldier killed in the fighting in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Court Dismisses Guilty Plea by Australian Tennis Star Nick Kyrgios in Assault Case
item.description: The guilty plea and dismissal stemmed from a confrontation Mr. Kyrgios had with his partner in 2021 when she tried to prevent him from leaving in a ride-hailing car.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Nick Kyrgios arriving at court in Canberra, Australia, on Friday.

item.title: As Russia Strikes Ukrainian Civilians, Putin Tells His People the War Is Just
item.description: Invoking World War II on the 80th anniversary of victory at Stalingrad, Mr. Putin repeated his false justifications for an invasion that has taken a staggering toll.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the rubble of an apartment building destroyed by a Russian attack, emergency workers in Kramatorsk searched for survivors on Thursday.

item.title: Biden Aims to Deter China With Greater U.S. Military Presence in Philippines
item.description: U.S. officials say they are preparing to surge forces in the event of conflict with China, including over Taiwan, but do not intend to build up permanent bases.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The new agreement allows the United States to put military equipment and build facilities in nine locations across the Philippines.

item.title: Soaring Russian Death Toll in Ukraine Gives Grim Insight Into the War
item.description: Moscow is sending poorly trained recruits, including convicts, to the front lines in eastern Ukraine to pave the way for more seasoned fighters, U.S. and allied officials say.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian medical evacuation team members await calls for wounded soldiers in the Donbas region in eastern Ukraine, which has been the scene of heavy fighting.

item.title: U.S. Says Russian Olympians Should Only Compete as Neutral Participants
item.description: The stance differs from the full ban demanded by Ukraine and supported by some of its allies.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russia’s Olympic athletes, including the figure skater Anna Shcherbakova, participated in the last Winter Olympics under the name and flag of the Russian Olympic Committee.

item.title: Peru Official Concedes There’s No Evidence Criminals Are Behind Protests
item.description: In an interview, Foreign Minister Ana Cecilia Gervasi acknowledged “we don’t have any evidence” that weeks of protests were being driven by criminal groups, as the country’s president has claimed.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Marco Garro for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest against the government of President Dina Boluarte last month in Lima, Peru.

item.title: High-Profile Raids Showcase Zelensky’s Corruption Crackdown in Ukraine
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky is eager to highlight his crackdown on corruption, ahead of E.U. accession talks and possible Western investigations of war aid.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has pivoted to a policy of high-profile anti-corruption enforcement this year.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: The U.S. Military Expands in the Philippines
item.description: Also, Vladimir Putin evokes Stalingrad and a contested film is a box-office hit in India.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Rolex Dela Pena
item.media:description: US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin reviewing honor guards upon arrival at the Department of National Defense at Camp Aguinaldo military camp in Quezon City, Metro Manila on Thursday.

item.title: Britain to Investigate if Deadliest Attack of Northern Ireland’s ‘Troubles’ Was Preventable
item.description: The decision is a big victory for the families of the 29 people who died in the attack in August 1998, four months after the signing of the Good Friday Agreement.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Paul Mcerlane/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The scene of a bomb explosion on Market Street in Omagh, Northern Ireland, on Aug. 15, 1998.

item.title: Tortured Guantánamo Detainee Is Freed in Belize
item.description: Majid Khan, a Pakistani citizen who attended high school in Maryland, finished his sentence last year.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: A Proud Ship Turned Into a Giant Recycling Problem. So Brazil Plans to Sink It.
item.description: The old aircraft carrier, once the navy’s flagship, is packed with asbestos. No country, including Brazil, will let it dock to be dismantled.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:description: The São Paulo, a Clemenceau-class carrier laid down in 1957, has not seen active service in roughly a decade.

item.title: Window Stickers to Prevent Bird Strikes Only Work One Way
item.description: Every year, hundreds of millions of birds die in the United States from flying into glass. New research shows how to prevent some of those deaths.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:description: Other big threats to birds: Habitat lost to development, climate change and hunting by cats.

item.title: Encouraging Economic Signs
item.description: New data suggests a promising possibility for the economy — that the U.S. avoids big job losses.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell.

item.title: Top E.U. Officials Arrive in Kyiv for a Summit With Zelensky
item.dc:creator: Erin Mendell
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky and Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, greeting each other during the E.U.-Ukraine summit in Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. and Philippines Have a Complex Military Alliance: What to Know
item.description: The United States and the Philippines have announced a plan to broaden American military access. The alliance is complicated by colonial history and rising tensions over Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Rolex Dela Pena
item.media:description: Lloyd J. Austin III, the U.S. defense secretary, center, arriving at Camp Aguinaldo, a military base in Quezon City, the Philippines, on Thursday.

item.title: After Jacinda Ardern, Politics Will Never Look the Same
item.description: For once, a politician who wasn’t afraid of fashion.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:description: Jacinda Ardern, the former prime minister of New Zealand, wore a burgundy jacket and matching shirt by the New Zealand label Maaike at her election night party in 2017, setting the tone for how fashion would figure into her leadership.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: The start of a new Russian offensive.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian forces training in the Zaporizhzhia region on Monday.

item.title: What ‘No’ on F-16 Fighter Jets Might Mean for Ukraine
item.description: If the usual script plays out, the Biden administration’s reluctance to provide the planes could be temporary, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Ukraine has asked for dozens of F-16s, which were developed in the 1970s by General Dynamics and the U.S. Air Force.

item.title: How an American Veterans Group Imploded in Ukraine
item.description: The Mozart Group was training Ukrainian soldiers and evacuating frontline residents until the money ran out. Its collapse sheds light on the stresses faced by such groups.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rob, left, a member of the Mozart Group, training Ukrainian soldiers last year.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Rising Militancy in Pakistan
item.description: Also, Adani Enterprises pulls its offering and soldiers die on both sides in Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: The bombing of a mosque in Peshawar, Pakistan, knocked the city back in time, to an era where terrorist attacks were more prevalent.

item.title: Russian Troop Buildup Signals Big New Assault, Ukraine Says
item.description: Russia is massing hundreds of thousands of troops and stepping up its bombardment, perhaps signaling the biggest assault since the start of the war. “I think it has started,” Ukraine’s leader says.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian forces training in the Zaporizhzhia region on Monday.

item.title: Navalny Says He Is Being Further Isolated in Russian Prison
item.description: “Even maniacs and serial killers serving life sentences have the right to receive a visit, but I don’t,” the Russian opposition leader wrote on Twitter.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Alexander Zemlianichenko/Russian Federal Penitentiary Service, via Associated Press

item.title: Memphis’s Scorpion Unit Is the Latest Special Unit to Come Under Fire
item.description: Memphis’s Scorpion is the latest special police unit to come under scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: The Memphis Police Department’s Scorpion unit in 2021.

item.title: Radioactive Capsule Is Found in Australia After 6-Day Search
item.description: The authorities had feared it would take weeks to scour hundreds of miles of an Australian desert for the pea-sized device.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Australian Department of Fire and Emergency Services
item.media:description: Searching for a radioactive capsule that had vanished in the Australian outback.

item.title: Covid Vaccine Makers Kept Prepayments for Canceled Shots for Poor Nations
item.description: Separately, Johnson & Johnson is demanding additional payment for unwanted shots, confidential documents show.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: Nepalese health workers prepared Covid vaccines, obtained through the Covax program, for storage in Kathmandu, Nepal, in 2021.

item.title: Green Comet Watching and More February Space and Astronomy Events
item.description: The shortest month of 2023 will have plenty of highlights in orbit and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Michael Roston
item.media:credit: Roscosmos State Space Corporation, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The International Space Station will have a busy month, receiving an empty Russian Soyuz capsule and a SpaceX spacecraft with a fresh crew of four astronauts.

item.title: Pope Francis, in Africa, Urges an End to Congo’s Cycle of Violence
item.description: Francis began the second day of his visit to Africa with a direct appeal to the warring groups in the Democratic Republic of Congo to put down their weapons and forgive one another.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Pope Francis greeting crowds at an airfield in Kinshasa, the Democratic Republic of Congo, on Wednesday. He was met by about a million people, a turnout not seen in years.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Europe’s economic recovery.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Volkswagen factory in Dresden, Germany. Although there are signs that Europe may avoid a recession, the German economy contracted in the fourth quarter.

item.title: Administration Expected to Endorse Limited Drilling in Alaska Project
item.description: An environmental review expected soon would effectively signal that the Willow project proceed, according to people familiar with the report.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Environmentalists have criticized the project as counter to President Biden’s climate pledges. Supporters say it would create jobs and support the state financially.

item.title: Russia Floods Ukrainian City of Bakhmut With Troops
item.description: The battle in the eastern Ukraine city of Bakhmut is growing in importance, as both sides pour forces into the battle.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident on the eastern side of Bakhmut, Ukraine, receiving food from a Ukrainian soldier in January.

item.title: U.S. Charges Four in Connection With the Assassination of Haiti’s President
item.description: The decision to charge the men, considered to be ringleaders in the assassination plot, in the United States is an indication of the chronic dysfunction of the Haitian justice system.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:description: A portrait of President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti at his memorial service in Port-au-Prince. The charges outlined a sprawling conspiracy to assassinate him.

item.title: Air Force Says Proposed Chinese-Owned Mill in North Dakota Is ‘Significant Threat’
item.description: A proposal for a corn mill, which had been welcomed as an economic development success, reflects just how much things have changed with Chinese investment proposals in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)
item.media:credit: Lewis Ableidinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: The proposed site of the Fufeng mill in Grand Forks, N.D.

item.title: U.S. Courts India as Technology Partner to Counter China
item.description: American and Indian officials are working toward new partnerships in defense technology, advanced telecom and semiconductors.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and President Biden said in May that they would begin talks about critical technology.

item.title: Netanyahu Juggles Competing Goals Over Palestinian Attacks
item.description: After a deadly week, Benjamin Netanyahu faces domestic calls for a harsh crackdown, and international pressure to moderate. It’s a familiar balancing act — but with one major difference.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu arriving at a cabinet meeting in Jerusalem on Sunday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: China Rebounds
item.description: Also, Russia’s resilient economy and Sri Lanka’s enduring struggle.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Villages across China are returning to normal.

item.title: Pakistan Grapples with Terrorist Attack That Left 101 Dead
item.description: The attack raised fears of a new wave of militancy from the Pakistani Taliban and sparked a heated debate over the government’s ability to meet that threat amid an economic and political crisis.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Salman Masood and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: The bombing of a mosque in Peshawar, Pakistan, knocked the city back in time, to an era where terrorist attacks were more prevalent.

item.title: Support for Tunisian President Slipping After Parliament Vote
item.description: Turnout was meager in two rounds of voting for a Parliament stripped of much of its power, with most political parties barred from the elections.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Ahmed Ellali
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:description: Farouk Bouasker, president of the Tunisian electoral authority, announced some turnout results on Sunday for the second round of the parliamentary elections the capital, Tunis.

item.title: Brexit Turns 3. Why Is No One Wearing a Party Hat?
item.description: The divorce between Britain and the European Union has become the dark thread that, to many, explains why Britain is suffering more than its neighbors.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: The International Monetary Fund said this week that Britain would be the world’s only major economy to contract in 2023, performing even worse than blacklisted Russia.

item.title: U.S. Says Russia Fails to Comply With Nuclear Arms Treaty
item.description: The United States says Russia is not allowing American inspectors access to its arsenal to ensure compliance with the New START agreement, which the two nations renewed in 2021.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: The full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February last year by the Russian military under the command of President Vladimir V. Putin makes any further negotiations over arms control difficult.

item.title: In Photos: Pope Francis Visits Africa
item.description: The pope’s trip began in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where the struggles of daily life are the very problems Francis has sought to highlight.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Crowds cheered as Pope Francis was driven through Martyrs Stadium in Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo, on Thursday.

item.title: Wagner Group May Have Committed War Crimes in Mali, UN Experts Say
item.description: Persistent reports point to “horrific executions” and other atrocities possibly committed by the Kremlin-affiliated mercenary force and the Malian military, according to human rights experts.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Wagner operatives at the Mopti airport, in central Mali, in February last year.

item.title: Iran and Russia Move Toward Linking Their Banking Systems
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had long been cautious about deepening ties to Iran, but his calculus has changed during the course of the war.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: The Central Bank of the Islamic Republic of Iran in Tehran.

item.title: Visiting Congo, Pope Francis Embraces the Poor and Exploited
item.description: The Central African country is wracked by war, poverty and environmental plunder — and it may be the future of the Catholic Church.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: Francis arriving at N’djili International Airport in Kinshasa on Tuesday. He is the first pope to visit the Democratic Republic of Congo since 1985.

item.title: France’s Pension Plan Strikes, Explained
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron is forging ahead with plans to raise the legal age of retirement to 64, from 62, despite strikes, street demonstrations and a looming parliamentary battle.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Protesters in Nantes, France, during a nationwide strike in late January to voice their anger over proposed changes to the pension system.
